articles.title: Ursula von der Leyen and Christine Lagarde congratulated Bulgaria on its accession to the euro area
articles.summary: At midnight Bulgaria introduces the euro as its official currency and becomes the 21st member of the EU monetary union
articles.content:
At midnight Bulgaria introduces the euro as its official currency and becomes the 21st member of the EU monetary union

BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT – The President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen and the President of the European Central Bank Christine Lagarde welcomed Bulgaria on the occasion of the country’s accession to the euro area, which will take place in a few hours.

Congratulations, Bulgaria! You can be proud of what you have achieved. Bulgaria is joining the euro area, one of the EU’s greatest achievements. This important milestone reflects years of hard work and commitment, overcoming challenges, said Ursula von der Leyen.

The euro will bring benefits to the Bulgarian people by making payments and travel easier. It will provide new opportunities for Bulgarian business and will further strengthen Bulgaria’s voice in Europe. This step is good for Bulgaria and strengthens Europe. It makes our economy more resilient and competitive on a global scale, added the President of the EC.

The Commission has fully supported Bulgaria in the process of joining the euro. With Bulgaria’s accession, 21 EU countries and over 357 million European citizens will share the common currency. Public support for the euro in the EU and the euro area remains very strong, with a large majority of citizens believing that the euro is something good for the EU and for their country, as shown by the latest Eurobarometer survey, the EC adds.

The President of the European Central Bank Christine Lagarde expressed gratitude to the Bulgarian National Bank for its dedicated work and commitment in preparing for the adoption of the euro and extended wishes for a happy and successful New Year.

With the arrival of 2026, we proudly welcome Bulgaria into the euro family, Lagarde wrote in a post on the social network Facebook.

The statement is part of a series of public comments by Christine Lagarde in the last weeks of 2025, marking Bulgaria’s progress towards membership in the euro area.

This is a historic moment that will strengthen trade, travel and financial stability across Europe, Lagarde wrote in one of these posts.

The European Central Bank will mark Bulgaria’s accession with an official visual projection on the southern facade of its main building in Frankfurt. The animation will include the greeting “Welcome, Bulgaria” in all the languages of the euro area countries, as well as a visual representation of the national side of the Bulgarian 50 cent, 1 euro and 2 euro coins.

The projection will last about four minutes and will be shown from 1 to 11 January 2026, with its first showing on New Year’s Eve. The visual elements will be in the colors of the European Union and will be synchronized with the music of the “Ode to Joy”.

Bulgaria will officially adopt the euro and will become the 21st member of the euro area as of 1 January 2026 – 19 years after the country’s accession to the European Union. The Council of the EU voted unanimously on 8 July this year on the final decisions related to the adoption of the euro in Bulgaria. With this, the procedure was completed, after earlier the same day the European Parliament also approved by a large majority the report on the introduction of the single European currency by Bulgaria. (31.12.2025)
articles.reasoning: Bulgaria's accession to the euro area represents a significant economic and political milestone with broad benefits for its citizens and the EU, enhancing financial stability, trade, and integration across Europe. The article provides detailed context on the event's significance and the positive impact on millions of Europeans.

This makes Bulgaria the 21st country to join the euro area, which is the group of EU countries that use the euro. The European Commission and the European Central Bank welcomed Bulgaria’s new membership.

**Impact** – Using the euro will make it easier for Bulgarians to travel and make payments across Europe. It will also help Bulgarian businesses by opening new opportunities and making the economy stronger and more competitive. With Bulgaria joining, over 357 million people in the euro area will share the same currency, helping to connect countries and improve trade.

**What's next step** – The European Central Bank will celebrate Bulgaria’s entry with a special light show in Frankfurt, Germany, from January 1 to 11, 2026. Meanwhile, Bulgaria will continue to strengthen its role in the EU economy, benefiting from closer ties with other euro area countries.

articles.title: Intriguing finds could solve mystery of women in medieval cemetery
articles.summary: There is growing evidence that the women were part of an early female religious community.
articles.content:
Intriguing finds could solve mystery of women in medieval cemetery

4 hours ago Share Save Rebecca Morelle , Science Editor and Alison Francis , Senior Science Journalist Share Save

Kevin Church/BBC News These tiny beads could have been stitched onto clothing or attached to jewellery

Intriguing new discoveries in a medieval cemetery in Wales have brought archaeologists closer to solving the mystery surrounding the women buried there. They've found what appears to be a small building and have unearthed domestic and decorative artefacts, including exquisite coloured glass beads. So far 58 skeletons, dating to the 6th or 7th Century, have been uncovered at the site. What's unusual is that nearly all belonged to women. The new finds add to growing evidence that the burial ground was part of an early female religious community.

Kevin Church/BBC News The 1,500-year-old skeletons are intact and well preserved

For the last four years, archaeologists have been excavating the site in the grounds of Fonmon Castle, close to the end of the runway at Cardiff airport. The skeletons are buried in shallow graves cut into the limestone bedrock. While their bones and teeth show they lived hard lives, objects found amongst the graves suggest wealth and luxury. The team have been scratching their heads trying to work out who these women were. Now the latest dig has provided a major clue: the outline of what could possibly be a small building. "It's producing fragments of building stone, so it might be structural. We might be thinking of a small shrine or a chapel," says Dr Andy Seaman, from Cardiff University, who is leading the dig. "I do think that we have a site which may be an early religious community."

Kevin Church/BBC News Graves are clustered around the possible building, which is highlighted in pink

The potential building is located in the centre of the cemetery and graves are clustered around it. It seems that people wanted to be buried as close to this feature as possible. So close in fact, says Cardiff University archaeologist Tudur Davies, that some of these graves have several people in them. "It's a highly desired location for people to be buried in," he says. "Sometimes two, three, four individuals have been buried on the same spot, again and again. There doesn't appear to be as much of a taboo over putting bodies in the same place and just moving those still there to one side." Artefacts found at the site are revealing more about the people buried here.

Kevin Church/BBC News Items include a copper brooch, a decorated bone pin and a comb carved from antler

The objects have been taken to Cardiff University's lab. Conservator Clare Emerson is painstakingly removing the dirt of the dig from an ornate copper brooch. "We'd have to do some more analysis, but it's probably bronze," she says. "Also we think it was possibly gilded, which would be a coating of gold over the top." The ends, she explains, were covered in green enamel. "This would have been a very decorative brooch. I think it's a very special find for the site." Alongside this piece of medieval bling, the team have also unearthed a pin made from bone with a detailed pattern and a comb intricately carved from antler. And there are some exquisite, multicoloured glass beads. Measuring about 3mm across, each one is a miniature delight. They were possibly stitched onto clothing or attached to a piece of jewellery.

Kevin Church/BBC News Fragments of glassware were found amongst the graves

But the domestic items found at the site tell us a lot too. "We have a quern stone for grinding flour for bread. We've got pottery and glass for eating and drinking" says Dr Andy Seaman. "It's clearly not just a place for the dead. There's a living community here as well." He thinks that the community was enclosed, living right next door to the cemetery, separated from the rest of society.

Kevin Church/BBC News Little is known about early religious communities from this area

The pieces of this medieval puzzle are starting to come together. But there are still some questions. The remains of a few men have been found - who were they? And some children too - were they related to any of the women? And while most of the people at the cemetery were buried with great care, two women were tossed in a ditch - one with her hands and feet tied. What had they done to deserve that?

Kevin Church/BBC News The excavations will continue at the site in 2026
articles.reasoning: The article reports on significant archaeological discoveries that provide meaningful insights into early female religious communities, enriching historical knowledge and cultural understanding. The findings have broad educational and societal value, revealing new information about medieval life and gender roles, and are supported by detailed evidence and ongoing research.
articles.personality_title: Archaeologists uncover clues to early female religious community in medieval Wales
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Archaeologists have been digging at a medieval cemetery near Cardiff airport in Wales, where they found mostly women’s skeletons dated to the 6th or 7th century. The site has puzzled researchers because of the unusual number of female burials.

**What happened** – Recent discoveries at the site include the outline of a small building, possibly a chapel or shrine, surrounded by clustered graves. The team also found delicate items like coloured glass beads, a decorated bone pin, a gilded copper brooch, and a carved antler comb. These objects suggest that the women may have belonged to a wealthy and special community. The presence of household items like a stone for grinding flour shows people lived nearby.

**Impact** – These findings support the idea that this cemetery was part of one of the earliest female religious communities in the region. It helps us understand more about women’s roles in medieval society and religion, a topic with few surviving records. The careful burials near the building show the community’s importance, while the rare discoveries of men and children’s remains raise new questions.

**What's next step** – Excavations will continue in 2026 to find more evidence. Researchers plan to study the artefacts further and investigate why some women were buried differently, including one found with hands and feet tied. This work could reveal more about the community’s daily life and social rules.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New archaeological finds in Wales reveal a rare early female religious community, shedding light on medieval women’s lives and faith.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des archéologues découvrent les traces d’une communauté religieuse féminine médiévale au Pays de Galles
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Des archéologues fouillent un cimetière médiéval près de l’aéroport de Cardiff au Pays de Galles, où ils ont trouvé principalement des squelettes de femmes datant du 6e ou 7e siècle. Le site intriguait les chercheurs à cause du nombre inhabituel de sépultures féminines.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des découvertes récentes montrent l’empreinte d’un petit bâtiment, peut-être une chapelle, entouré de tombes regroupées. L’équipe a aussi trouvé des objets délicats comme des perles de verre colorées, une épingle en os décorée, une broche en cuivre dorée et un peigne en bois de cerf sculpté. Ces objets suggèrent que ces femmes appartenaient à une communauté riche et spéciale. La présence d’objets domestiques comme une pierre à moudre indique qu’ils vivaient à proximité.

**Impact** – Ces trouvailles confirment que ce cimetière faisait partie d’une des premières communautés religieuses féminines dans la région. Elles aident à mieux comprendre le rôle des femmes au Moyen Âge, un sujet peu documenté. Les sépultures soignées près du bâtiment montrent l’importance de cette communauté, tandis que la découverte rare d’hommes et d’enfants soulève de nouvelles questions.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les fouilles continueront en 2026 pour trouver plus de preuves. Les chercheurs vont étudier les objets en détail et chercher à comprendre pourquoi certaines femmes ont été enterrées différemment, notamment une avec les mains et les pieds liés. Ces recherches pourraient révéler plus sur la vie quotidienne et les règles sociales de la communauté.

**Message clé en une phrase** – De nouvelles découvertes archéologiques au Pays de Galles révèlent une rare communauté religieuse féminine ancienne, éclairant la vie et la foi des femmes médiévales.
articles.personality_title_es: Arqueólogos descubren pistas sobre una comunidad religiosa femenina medieval en Gales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Arqueólogos han estado excavando en un cementerio medieval cerca del aeropuerto de Cardiff en Gales, donde encontraron principalmente esqueletos de mujeres del siglo VI o VII. El sitio ha desconcertado a los investigadores por la cantidad inusual de enterramientos femeninos.

**Qué pasó** – Descubrimientos recientes incluyen el contorno de un pequeño edificio, posiblemente una capilla, rodeado de tumbas agrupadas. El equipo también encontró objetos delicados como cuentas de vidrio de colores, un alfiler decorado de hueso, un broche de cobre dorado y un peine tallado en asta. Estos objetos sugieren que las mujeres pertenecían a una comunidad rica y especial. La presencia de objetos domésticos como una piedra para moler muestra que vivían cerca.

**Impacto** – Estos hallazgos apoyan la idea de que este cementerio formaba parte de una de las primeras comunidades religiosas femeninas de la región. Ayuda a entender mejor el papel de las mujeres en la sociedad y religión medieval, un tema con pocos registros. Los entierros cuidadosos cerca del edificio muestran la importancia de la comunidad, mientras que los restos raros de hombres y niños plantean nuevas preguntas.

**Próximo paso** – Las excavaciones continuarán en 2026 para encontrar más evidencia. Los investigadores planean estudiar los artefactos con más detalle e investigar por qué algunas mujeres fueron enterradas de forma diferente, incluyendo una encontrada con manos y pies atados. Este trabajo podría revelar más sobre la vida diaria y las reglas sociales.

**Resumen en una frase** – Nuevos hallazgos arqueológicos en Gales revelan una rara comunidad religiosa femenina temprana, iluminando la vida y fe de las mujeres medievales.

articles.title: Bulgaria receives third payment of EUR 1.47 billion under the Recovery and Resilience Plan
articles.summary: With this payment, the funds received during the year from the EC in Bulgaria amount in total to 1.9 billion euros
articles.content:
With this payment, the funds received during the year from the EC in Bulgaria amount in total to 1.9 billion euros

SOFIA – Bulgaria has received a third payment of 1.47 billion euros under the National Recovery and Resilience Plan (NRRP), the Council of Ministers of the country announced. The payment was made after the European Commission (EC) assessed 48 out of a total of 50 milestones and targets included in the payment request as fulfilled.

The third payment request covers 22 reforms and 19 investments and is the largest submitted so far. The main measures reported with it are related to continuing reforms in areas such as research and innovation, decarbonization, public procurement, improving the governance framework for state-owned enterprises, development of e-government and e-healthcare, etc., the government press service added.

With this payment, the funds received from the EC during the year amount to a total of 1.9 billion euros, which exceeds more than half of the payments under the Plan.

In the first half of 2026, the fourth and fifth payments under the NRRP, worth nearly 2.5 billion euros, must be serviced, said Deputy Prime Minister and resigning Minister of Innovation and Growth Tomislav Donchev to the cabinet ministers. He added that the plan had been renegotiated, which made it possible for a large part of the reforms to be supported and implemented. The government also managed to negotiate the REPowerEU chapter worth an additional 480 million euros, noted the resigning Deputy Prime Minister. Donchev added that if the funds from cohesion policy disbursed during this year are also included, then the European funds invested in the Bulgarian economy amount to 8 billion leva. The Bulgarian Recovery and Resilience Plan amounts to 6.17 billion euros in grants. (29-30.12.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant financial milestone in Bulgaria's National Recovery and Resilience Plan, with large payments from the European Commission supporting reforms and investments in research, innovation, decarbonization, e-government, and e-healthcare. This has a broad positive impact on Bulgaria's economy and governance, benefiting society at large. The story is focused and provides sufficient context about the reforms and funding scale.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria receives 1.47 billion euros to support major reforms and investments
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria is part of a European Union plan called the National Recovery and Resilience Plan (NRRP). This plan gives money to help countries make important changes and improvements in areas like technology, the environment, and government services.

**What happened** – Bulgaria received its third payment of 1.47 billion euros from the European Commission. This payment came after the EU confirmed that Bulgaria completed most of the goals it set for this stage. The payment supports 22 reforms and 19 investments, including projects in research, cleaner energy, better public services, and new digital tools for healthcare and government.

**Impact** – This is the largest payment Bulgaria has received so far under the plan. With this latest amount, Bulgaria has now received 1.9 billion euros this year, which is more than half of the total funding planned. The money helps Bulgaria improve how it works and supports important projects that affect many people.

**What's next step** – Bulgaria plans to receive two more payments worth nearly 2.5 billion euros in the first half of 2026. These funds will continue to support the country’s reforms and investments. The government has also secured extra money, about 480 million euros, for energy projects through a new EU program called REPowerEU.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria has made strong progress in its recovery plan, receiving a large EU payment to fund important reforms and investments that will benefit the country’s future.
